name: Porto
fun_fact: Fun fact: The famous Francesinha sandwich was invented in the 1950s when Portuguese emigrant Daniel Silva returned from France and thought 'hey, let's go bigger' after seeing the croque-monsieur. The result? A monstrous sandwich with two types of sausages, ham, beef steak, melted cheese, and beer sauce that has become one of the top ten sandwiches in the world.

hero_dishes.name: Francesinha
hero_dishes.description: A caloric bomb sandwich featuring layers of beef steak, cured meat, fresh sausages, topped with cheese, covered in spicy beer-tomato sauce, and surrounded by French fries
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in the 1950s by Daniel Silva, who adapted the French croque-monsieur into something distinctly Portuguese and much larger. The name means 'Little French Girl' - ironic given there's nothing little about it. It's Porto's most iconic culinary symbol.

hero_dishes.name: Bifana
hero_dishes.description: Juicy pork steak sandwich stewed in tomato, wine, piri piri, garlic and olive oil sauce, served in a carca√ßa bun
hero_dishes.origin_story: Humble working-class origins from Portuguese kitchens. Porto's bifanas are saucier and more flavorful than southern Portugal versions - the north uses shredded pork with sauce, while the south uses lighter cutlets.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Sandeira (near Rua das Flores) - cozy spot, hard to find a table but worth it for delicious sandwiches

hero_dishes.origin_story: Classic Portuguese petisco with uncertain history, but Porto's affinity for seafood and global spices led to their development. Often paired with an 'imperial' (small beer) as the perfect snack.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Xau Laura (near Crystal Palace Gardens) - affordable prices, crispy and tasty riss√≥is; traditional caf√©s throughout Baixa district

hero_dishes.name: Petiscos
hero_dishes.description: Portuguese 'tapas' - small shareable dishes to accompany wine; the word 'petiscar' means to savor something special
hero_dishes.origin_story: Portuguese pride themselves on petiscos being distinctly NOT Spanish tapas. It's about licking your fingers, refreshing your soul with beer, tasting wines and socializing - food is about people and community.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional tascas (taverns) in Baixa; Adega S√£o Nicolau and Taberna dos Mercadores for authentic experience away from tourist traps

signature_drinks.name: Port Wine
signature_drinks.description: Sweet fortified wine in varieties like Ruby (young, fruity), Tawny (aged, complex), and Vintage
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Perfect for accompanying typical Porto dishes. Ironically, many famous Port wines are stored and aged across the Douro River in Vila Nova de Gaia, not Porto proper.

signature_drinks.name: Vinho Verde
signature_drinks.description: Light and refreshing white wine signature to the region
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served at traditional tascas while mingling with locals over petiscos in neighborhood taverns
